chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Gingivitis and periodontitis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of clinically apparent plaque-associated gingivitis, with or without periodontitis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage someone with suspected plaque-associated gingivitis/periodontitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If there are any concerning features, such as:
    • Unexplained or atypical enlargement of the gingivae — consider the possibility of leukaemia and investigate and refer appropriately.
    • Periodontitis presenting in children or young adults, or progressing rapidly — consider the possibility of serious conditions such as aggressive periodontitis, immunosuppression, and malignancy.
    • Unexplained ulceration in the oral cavity lasting for more than 3 weeks — consider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) for oral cancer.
    • Either a lump on the lip or in the oral cavity, or a red or red and white patch in the oral cavity consistent with erythroplakia or erythroleukoplakia — consider an urgent referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) to a dentist for assessment for possible oral cancer.
      • If there is a strong suspicion of oral cancer and/or there is likely to be a delay in the person accessing a dentist, use clinical judgement and consider referring urgently using a local suspected cancer referral pathway (to be seen within 2 weeks) or seek immediate advice from an oral medicine or oral and maxillofacial specialist.
  • Advise routine regular review by a dentist or hygienist.
    • Review interval will depend on the advice of the dentist.
    • People with predisposing risk factors may require frequent professional cleaning.
    • For people with diabetes, explain that they are at increased risk of periodontal (gum) disease and encourage them to make a dental appointment as soon as possible. 
  • Give advice on oral hygiene. Advise the person to remove plaque by:
    • Brushing their teeth for two minutes twice a day (in the morning and last thing at night), preferably with a powered toothbrush.
      • Advise that toothbrushes should have a small head with medium texture bristles and should be replaced when signs of wear appear (every one to three months).
      • Advise use of a fluoride-containing toothpaste and to 'spit don't rinse' when cleaning teeth.
      • Refer people who are unable to use a toothbrush to a dentist. 
    • Daily interdental cleaning before brushing teeth.
      • Choice of interdental cleaning aid will depend on personal preference. However, advise that for most people with periodontitis, interdental brushes will be more effective than dental floss or tape because of the size of their interdental spaces. People with varying interdental gaps (common in periodontitis) will need several different sizes of interdental brush. Brushes should fit into the interdental space without the wire rubbing the tooth. 
  • Do not routinely recommend mouthwashes.
  • Antibiotics are not usually necessary and should be prescribed only on the advice of a specialist.
  • Offer smoking cessation advice if appropriate. For more information, see the CKS topic on Smoking cessation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Management of concerning features
  • The recommendation on urgent referral for unexplained gingival enlargement is based on guidelines from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme on Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care which state that this can be a sign of undiagnosed leukaemia in adults and children and urgent referral to a physician should be considered if the clinical picture is inconsistent with the person's level of oral hygiene [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014].
  • The recommendation to consider underlying conditions such as aggressive periodontitis, malignancy, and immunosuppression in young people with periodontitis, or people in whom periodontitis is progressing rapidly is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article [Coventry et al, 2000]. Aggressive periodontitis is rapidly progressive and usually affects people less than 35 years of age [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
  • The recommendation on considering a suspected cancer pathway referral for unexplained ulceration in the oral cavity lasting for more than 3 weeks is based on guidelines on Suspected cancer: recognition and referral published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2015].
  • The recommendation on considering an urgent referral to a dentist for a lump on the lip or in the oral cavity, or a red or red and white patch in the oral cavity is based on guidelines on Suspected cancer: recognition and referral published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2015].
    • CKS has made the pragmatic recommendation to consider an urgent referral or seek immediate advice from an oral medicine or oral and maxillofacial specialist if there is a strong suspicion of cancer and/or the person is unlikely to be able to promptly access a dentist, to reduce the risk of delaying a diagnosis of cancer if a referral pathway to a dentist is not available. This is approach is based on expert opinion in a review article [Grimes et al, 2016] and Cancer Research UK referral pathway recommendations [Cancer Research UK, 2015].
Referral to a dentist for treatment of gingivitis or periodontitis
  • CKS recommends referral to a dentist for a full assessment and confirmation of the diagnosis if gingivitis or periodontitis is suspected because professional scaling and polishing and root surface instrumentation (cleaning of the tooth's root surface below the gum) by a dentist or hygienist using specialist equipment are required to treat gingivitis and periodontitis [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016; British Society of Periodontology, 2016]. Toothbrushing, flossing, and mouthwashes have an effect only above and slightly below the gum level. They are therefore ineffective in treating periodontitis, as plaque and calculus continues to accumulate below the gum line within periodontal pockets [BMJ Best Practice, 2016; British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
  • Management of factors leading to plaque collection such as malpositioned teeth and dental interventions such as crowns, bridgework, and fixed orthodontic appliances, and removal of calculus are also important in the treatment and prevention of periodontal disease and require the expertise of a dentist [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
Review interval
  • Regular review at the dentist ensures timely detection and treatment of problems such as excessive plaque and calculus that can lead to, or aggravate, periodontal disease.
    • A Cochrane systematic review (search date September 2013) aimed to determine the relative beneficial and harmful effects of different recall intervals (such as 6 months) between dental check-ups [Riley et al, 2013]. The authors found only one study that met the inclusion criteria (n = 185) but this was assessed as having a high risk of bias and provided very low-quality evidence. It was therefore not possible to draw any conclusions about the practice of encouraging people to attend for dental check-ups every 6 months.
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that the usual interval for maintenance dental review is 3–6 months, but if a person's plaque is not controlled, they should be seen more frequently [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • The recommendation to offer advice to people with diabetes and recommend they see a dentist is based on a guideline from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme: Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014] and expert opinion in a document from Public Health England on Delivering better oral health: an evidence-based toolkit for prevention [PHE, 2014]. This states that people with diabetes are at increased risk of developing periodontitis and may respond less well to treatment.
Oral hygiene measures
  • Oral hygiene is recommended as an important factor in the non-surgical treatment of periodontal disease in guidelines from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme: Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014] and the British Society of Periodontology: The good practitioner's guide to periodontology [British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
Powered and manual toothbrushing
  • The recommendations on toothbrushing are based on a guideline from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme: Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014], the British Society of Periodontology: The good practitioner's guide to periodontology [British Society of Periodontology, 2016], and an evidence-based toolkit from Public Health England on delivering better oral health [PHE, 2014]. 
    • A Cochrane systematic review (search date January 2014) compared powered and manual toothbrushing for oral health. Fifty-one trials (n = 4624) were included in a meta-analysis that found a statistically significant benefit in terms of plaque removal and gingivitis in the short and long term with powered toothbrushes compared with manual toothbrushes, based on moderate-quality evidence. There was heterogeneity between the included studies [Yaacob et al, 2014]. A subsequent meta-review (search date April 2014) had similar findings for gingivitis [Van der Weijden and Slot, 2015].
  • CKS recommends referral of people who are unable to use a toothbrush based on expert opinion from a Public Health England document Delivering better oral health: an evidence-based toolkit for prevention which advises additional support and toothbrush adaptation for people with limited cognitive and motor skills [PHE, 2014].
Interdental cleaning
  • The recommendation on daily interdental cleaning is based on an evidence-based toolkit from Public Health England on delivering better oral health [PHE, 2014] and a guideline from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme: Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014]. 
    • A Cochrane systematic review (search date October 2011) aimed to assess the effects of flossing in addition to toothbrushing compared to toothbrushing alone in the management of periodontal disease and dental caries in adults [Sambunjak et al, 2011]. 
      • Twelve trials (582 participants) were included in the review and all were assessed as being either at high risk or unclear risk of bias.
      • There was some evidence to suggest that toothbrushing plus flossing reduces gingivitis compared with toothbrushing alone.
    • A separate Cochrane systematic review (search date March 2013) compared the effectiveness of toothbrushing alone, toothbrushing plus flossing, and toothbrushing plus use of interdental brushes for a number of dental diagnoses including periodontal diseases [Poklepovic et al, 2013].
      • Interdental brushing plus toothbrushing was found to be more effective than toothbrushing alone for reducing gingivitis and plaque after one month in one study (n = 62, low-quality evidence).
      • Interdental brushing plus toothbrushing was found to be more effective than flossing plus toothbrushing at reducing gingivitis at one month based on data from seven studies (n = 326, low-quality evidence).
    • A subsequent meta-review (search date August 2014) comparing the efficacy of different interdental cleaning methods found six systematic reviews (including the Cochrane systematic review [Poklepovic et al, 2013]) [Salzer et al, 2015]. Interdental brushing was found to be most effective for plaque removal, with less evidence identified to demonstrate the effectiveness of flossing.
Mouthwashes
  • Mouthwashes are not routinely recommended for periodontal disease because although anti-plaque mouthwashes have a bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity and inhibit the development of plaque and gingivitis, they do not have a significant effect on established plaque, cannot penetrate into areas of pocketing, and do not stop periodontitis from progressing [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; BNF 72, 2016]. Toothbrushing and interdental cleaning is a more effective method of plaque removal [BNF 72, 2016].
  • However, expert opinion states that there may be a role for the use of mouthwashes with antimicrobial and antiplaque properties in people for whom toothbrushing and other mechanical methods of controlling dental plaque are painful or not possible [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016; British Society of Periodontology, 2016]. Note that chlorhexidine digluconate mouthwash is only licensed for 30 days of use [British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
Antibiotics
  • Guidance from the Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme on Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014] and the British Society of Periodontology: The good practitioner's guide to periodontology [British Society of Periodontology, 2016] state that systemic antibiotics should not be used to treat chronic periodontitis. It is acknowledged that there may be a role for systemic antibiotics in people with aggressive periodontitis, but these people should be under the care of a specialist [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014; British Society of Periodontology, 2016].
Smoking cessation
  • The recommendation to offer smoking cessation advice is based on the fact that smokers and users of smokeless tobacco products are at increased risk of developing periodontal disease and may have an impaired response to treatment [PHE, 2014].The good practitioner's guide to periodontology from the British Society of Periodontology discusses risk factor control, such as smoking cessation, as a key part of non-surgical therapy for periodontal disease [British Society of Periodontology, 2016]. Guidance from Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme on Prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases in primary care recommends giving people with periodontal disease smoking cessation advice on the basis that smoking is a risk factor for periodontitis (and oral cancer) and can negatively affect the response to treatment [Scottish Dental Clinical Effectiveness Programme, 2014]. This recommendation is also supported by expert opinion in a review article [Preshaw, 2015].
  • A systematic review (search date August 2012) investigating the effect of smoking cessation on the outcomes of non-surgical periodontal therapy included two studies that suggested a beneficial effect of smoking cessation in addition to non-surgical periodontal treatment. However, the authors commented on the limited amount of evidence available [Chambrone et al, 2013].
